body: This is a good idea. In addition to avoiding error of special tokens, it also simplifies the construction of the vocab for BERT (for example, set these special tokens as the default parameters of BERTVocab. Users don't need to modify it if there is no special requirement), so that the interface becomes easier to use and more elegant.
@kenjewu would you like to create a PR for it and replace the string literals in existing bert examples?
Ok! I will try to finish it.
That's why one of our earlier design for Vocab has a 'reserved_tokens' attribute to allow flexible extension.
Regarding a more general approach - can we extend the setattr/getattr method of Vocab class to allow registration of special tokens?

@astonzhang yes, exactly. The drawback with the reserved_tokens constructor field is that there's no special attribute or name to refer to them later.

@eric-haibin-lin this is what I had in mind too. We still need a way to be able to restrict the declaration of these special attributes during construction, or at least explictly by calling a special method, or otherwise people may run into issues that is extending these attributes unintentionally.

@eric-haibin-lin Currently not every attribute of Vocab is a special token, so overwriting the general `__setattr__` may be confusing. Maybe better to introduce something explicit? Eg either on the level of `reserved_tokens` or a separate method on the Vocab class?
@leezu Yes, adding a separate method allowing users to extend attributes sounds reasonable.
